Hitchens and Said Interestingly, Christopher Hitchens and Edward Said maintained a friendship for years. Here are links to articles by Hitchens that offer a much more nuanced portrait of Said than the one I wrote on 9/25/03. From The Atlantic : urlLink Where the Twain Should Have Met . Hitchens displays a sympathy for Said tempered by a disappointment that he failed to live up to his beliefs. In The Nation Hitchens defended Said against accusations by Justus Reid Weiner (update to my 9/25/03 entry) that Said urlLink had falsified parts of his autobiography . And in Slate Hitchens offers his urlLink affectionate obituary for Said, a man he admired for 25 years. Hitchens and Said also worked together on a book: urlLink Blaming the Victims: Spurious Scholarship and the Palestinian Question .

Edward Said, R.I.P. Martin Kramer wrote a short introduction to Said and his theories at his excellent blog urlLink Sandstorm (click on "Said's Splash"). According to Kramer, Edward Said was trained in English and comparative literature but became, by writing Orientalism , the intellectual source of the critical theory of post-colonialism. Kramer has spent a goodly amount of time pointing out the deeply pernicious effects of Orientalism and its spawn, the output of post-colonial theorists throughout the world. From what I can tell Said deserves our condemnation. He has abetted the politicization of Middle East studies, which has reached a stage wherein it is incapable of describing the truth of the Middle East, much less prescribing useful solutions to that region's woes. In the end, Said and the theoretical cadres surrounding his theories can fairly be charged with promoting a dangerous ignorance that has cost lives, Western and Arab. Said died at age 67 after a urlLink long struggle with leukemia . UPDATE: Edited the above to correct the use of post-colonialist where post-colonial was appropriate. Adding a link to urlLink a story in Salon describing Justus Reid Weiner's attack on Said's autobiography, Out of Place: A Memoir . See entry above for Christopher Hitchens's take on Said.

No words. I drew two towers within a pentagon on this day on my calendar. I put out the flag this morning. And I remembered that day. Brenda the temp came up to me while I was in the middle of something. I was busy and pre-occupied. She said, "An airplane has hit the World Trade Center." My mind couldn't change gears fast enough to handle that information; the best I could do was say "What?" But the look on her face told me -- it was the look I last saw on the face of the college kid who told me that the space shuttle Challenger had blown up, all those years before. No words seem sufficient for the grief I feel, the grief I see in the faces of those whose hearts were broken that day just as mine was broken. Just remember the burning buildings; just remember those who jumped rather than burn; just remember the men and women who rushed toward the destruction to help when their instincts told them to run the other way. Remember.

The lure of blood. Rereading my entry of Tuesday, October 14, it occurs to me how strong ties of kinship are compared to intellectual ties like nationality. When modern humans emerged from Africa they probably destroyed all competitors, because they cared only for their families and their kin. You see the strength of these ties still today, in places where family and clan are the basic social unit and nationhood is an artificial Western concept. Our civilization, which is much to be preferred to the state of nature, requires a constant input of intellectual and moral energy to sustain itself. People who speak casually of destroying or radically altering what we've built need to be reminded that, in a world where the clan rules, there is no room for dissent, aberration, eccentricity, and individualism. Many of those who loathe our civilization would be casually eradicated in the state of nature because they would have no role in the world of the clan. These thoughtless nihilists need to be reminded that everything they hate -- order, stability, the rule of law -- is necessary for a society that can tolerate them.

These advisors can see that the situation in Iraq, coupled with the sluggish economy, could make Bush a one-term president like his father. Blue Monday (A Little Cheese with that Whine?). I just took the test at urlLink AdultADD.com . Turns out I've got -- wait for it -- adult ADD. I had most of the symptoms: Difficulty concentrating, inability to organize, procrastination, bad memory for appointments and obligations. This is the second screening test that came up with that result. The psychopharmacologist that's prescribing my depression meds said that Welbutrin should do the trick. I didn't point out to her, but should have, that I've been taking Welbutrin for years now and it hasn't made a dent in the ADD symptoms. All this contemplating my weaknesses made me stare into space for a while, think about worst-case scenarios, miss my wife (who's working a double shift in order to make some extra money for Christmas) and really, really wish for a drink. I've been having a lot of that lately. I've been on the wagon for 7-1/2 years now and I'm proud of that, but if somebody handed me a drink right now I'd toss all those years of sobriety out the window and suck it right down just to get that feeling you get when you have the first drink. Everybody knows that feeling; it's like breathing clean air after walking through smog -- like falling back onto a featherbed after an exhausting day. It's relief in a glass. I miss that so very, very much these days, when I feel like there's nothing to my life, like I'm stuck in mud and I haven't accomplished a damn thing. When I was drunk I could put the fear and the envy and the sense of not belonging to the human race aside for a night. I could feel free and go bed and sleep deeply and not wake up in the morning stillness and wonder why the hell I was alive. That's the way down to where I was before, down to the place where I was less than human, more like an animal who cared only to eat, sleep, and get drunk. I'm not going there again -- I know what it's like now and I'm not sure I could survive it again. But some days I wish I could forget the animal times and just get that one sip, that taste of release. Just once, you know, and never again. You know, just like before.

Should I buy a gun? For some reason I don't understand I've started thinking about buying a gun. Maybe I'm having a midlife crisis, maybe I've been influenced by 9/11, maybe I'm turning into a crazed right-wing wacko. Whatever the answer, I've suddenly gotten this idea that now is the time to get a gun and I can't get the thought out of my head. On the other hand there's a part of my brain that says this is a stupid idea, I've gone round the bend, and I shouldn't even consider such a whacked-out idea. In the words of the King of Siam in The King and I , it is a puzzlement. Dad told me once that when you're of two minds about something you should take a piece of paper, draw a line down the center, and list the pros on one side and the cons on the other. In that spirit I present the following lists: Reasons to Own a Handgun 1. Home defense 2. Concealed carry for personal defense 3. Take up target shooting 4. Exercise 2nd Amendment rights 5. Always wanted to learn how to handle a firearm 6. Shooting is a sport I can share with my stepson (since he's young and lithe and I'm old and fat) 7. Need more fun in my life 8. Get me out of the house more often 9. Improve hand-eye coordination 10. It's got to be cheaper than messing around with computers Reasons for Not Owning a Handgun 1. Possibility of accidental discharge 2. Possibility of shooting a loved one by mistake 3. Young stepson could injure or kill himself with it if he isn't trained 4. From what I can tell it can be a pretty expensive hobby 5. Has a high learning curve 6. Might require more manual dexterity than I've got 7. Might get bored with it 8. Time consuming 9. Neighborhood is pretty quiet -- do I really need a gun? 10. Wife might freak out I've got to admit that 1, 2, 3, 9, and 10 are potential deal breakers. Given that these things are possibilities, however remote, can I really justify having a weapon that isn't really necessary? But then it's a dangerous world out there. But then...I don't know. Please comment if you've got an opinion, okay? Thanks.

I am grateful for my parents, who raised themselves from a modest station through hard work and tenacity and did the best they could to raise good children. I am grateful to the men who made possible a nation of laws wherein it is possible to pursue one's dreams relatively unmolested, resulting in historically unprecedented prosperity and freedom. I am grateful to the men and women, past, present, and future, who have and do and will put their lives on the line to ensure that me and mine can live in peace and security. And I must admit, I am grateful to God -- if he/she/it exists (just can't bring yourself to say it, can you Jon?) -- who has seen fit to bless me and mine with the best things in life. Good night, dear reader. Count your blessings and go with God. (There, I said it: Go with God.) (But do you believe it, truly believe that God exists?) (I don't know. (Truth in advertising: I know squat about ballistics, I've never served in the military, and I don't even own a firearm. Bring your salt shaker to the following post.) Not too many people in the US military like the 5.56 mm NATO round: it's just not much of a man-stopper, as troops in Afghanistan and Iraq have found, sometimes to their regret. Unfortunately, with an installed base of thousand of M16 assault rifles and M4 carbines using this round, there's plenty of inertial bureaucratic incentive to keep it around. That's where urlLink some guys from USSOCOM (US Special Operations Command) came in. On their own initiative they campaigned to come up with a more powerful round with better ballistic characteristics. Interestingly, they got support in this pursuit from some knowledgeable people in the military (like the US Army Marksmanship Unit). After much testing it was concluded that a 6.8 mm round was optimal for stopping power and ballistic characteristics. urlLink Then Remington got into the act and started producing limited quantities of this 6.8 mm SPC round. Great: But how to get it to the front-line troops? The problem is that large installed base of weapons chambered for the 5.56 mm NATO round (note that the 6.8 mm SPC round was specifically designed to fit existing M16/M4 magazines). (What follows is speculation on my part.) urlLink Enter Barrett Firearms, who produced an upper for the M16 that will chamber the new 6.8 mm SPC round. Why create such a thing if there was no market for it? Maybe there will be a market for it -- maybe the plan is to retrofit the rifles carried by front-line troops with this new upper so they can use the new round. That would be way cool, but there's another problem: The M16 is an old design. A guy named urlLink Eugene Stoner designed the M16 back in the mid-1950s and the state of the gunmaker's art has advanced since then. Quite by coincidence, the US military was working on the prototypes of a weapon called the urlLink OICW (Objective Individual Combat Weapon -- pentagonese at its worst) . It was an interesting idea: An assault rifle and a very smart grenade launcher all in one man-portable package. As the military tested it, however, they discovered that it really wasn't all that man-portable after all, and the program stalled. Meanwhile, word had percolated up from the troops that the M16/M4 just weren't good enough for modern combat. The military thrashed around looking for a replacement for Stoner's venerable design when somebody noticed that the assault rifle part of the OICW, made by the fine folks at the German firearms manufacturer urlLink Heckler & Koch , was a really good rifle based on a really good design (the H&K G36). Somebody -- most likely H&K themselves -- came up with the idea of separating the assault rifle part of the OICW from the grenade launcher part and making it into an assault rifle replacement. Thus was born the urlLink XM8 . Now, according to the fine folks at urlLink Picatinny Arsenal , the DoD unit responsible for getting armaments out to the soldiers, 5.56 mm NATO is the round for the US military: Discussions in forum on the Infantry Web site, www.infantry.army.mil, show some infantrymen question the value of fielding a new assault rifle delivering the same 5.56mm rounds already in service. They question the gain. Clarke, however, sees a lot of value added. On the other hand, Heckler & Koch seem to emphasize something of interest to this discussion: A unique feature of the XM8 modular weapon system is the ability to easily and quickly reconfigure the weapon from one variant to the other to meet changing mission requirements, to include caliber conversion . [Emphasis in original.] It's still a little bit mysterious, but then again the XM8 is supposed to be issued to the troops as early as mid-2006, so maybe the troops will finally get the round and the assault rifle that they need -- and deserve.

urlLink Wizbang (link via urlLink InstaPundit ) found urlLink this remarkable passage in the 9/11 Commission's final report: In this sense, 9/11 has taught us that terrorism against American interests “over there” should be regarded just as we regard terrorism against America “over here.” In this same sense, the American homeland is the planet. But the enemy is not just “terrorism,” some generic evil. This vagueness blurs the strategy. The catastrophic threat at this moment in history is more specific. It is the threat posed by Islamist terrorism —especially the al Qaeda network, its affiliates, and its ideology. As we mentioned in chapter 2, Usama Bin Ladin and other Islamist terrorist leaders draw on a long tradition of extreme intolerance within one stream of Islam (a minority tradition), from at least Ibn Taimiyyah, through the founders of Wahhabism, through the Muslim Brotherhood, to Sayyid Qutb. That stream is motivated by religion and does not distinguish politics from religion, thus distorting both. It is further fed by grievances stressed by Bin Ladin and widely felt throughout the Muslim world—against the U.S. military presence in the Middle East, policies perceived as anti-Arab and anti-Muslim, and support of Israel. Bin Ladin and Islamist terrorists mean exactly what they say: to them America is the font of all evil, the “head of the snake,” and it must be converted or destroyed. It is not a position with which Americans can bargain or negotiate. With it there is no common ground—not even respect for life—on which to begin a dialogue. It can only be destroyed or utterly isolated. There are two remarkable parts: (1) The claim that "the American homeland is the planet"; (2) The insistence that the radical stream of Islam can only be destroyed or isolated. The first claim is essentially imperial. I hate using that word because others have misused and perverted it with vicious glee, but it's the only one that fits what I think the Commission is getting at, which is that America has so many interests in so many places that any threat anywhere must necessarily impinge on one of those interests. This recognition is much like the logic of empire as recognized by the British, especially with respect to India. The second claim is the breathtaking one, coming as it does from a bipartisan commission. In frank, unambiguous language, a government body outside the control of the administration has said what the administration is probably thinking but cannot articulate, for fear of alienating its muslim allies: That there is a strain of Islam that cannot be allowed to spread, and must indeed be rolled back or destroyed. The commission has called down a fatwa on radical Islam in general and Wahhabism in particular. No wonder the major news outlets are ignoring this part of the commission's findings.

So it's another day of rain in southeast PA and all the frantic running around of the past few days has ground to a halt. I had two days off from work and I had vowed to use them to get all sorts of things done around the house. Some things I did, other things I started, and other things I ignored. Not a bad tally, considering my procrastinating tendencies, but I'm not willing to put any further effort out this week. I'm going to save my energies for work, which is going to be a treadmill in hell. Not to be too dramatic. Youngest stepson had a friend come for a sleepover. I could hear them horsing around at about 3:00 this morning, doing the things you do when you're a boy having a sleepover -- stay up late, engage in pointless but cool conspiracies, and then wake up and watch cartoons until it's time for the guest to go home. No worries. I miss "no worries." Still, being an adult has more compensations than drawbacks, if you ask me. I don't have to go to school if I don't want to, Mom and Dad can't make me eat things I don't want to eat, I can get in the car and go somewhere without having to pester somebody to give me a ride, and people actually pay attention to what I have to say (well, most of the time). Yes, you have to work and pay bills and worry about the kids and think about the future, but you have much more control over your own fate. The older I get, the more I find that I like the idea of controlling my own fate.

Consider the following thought experiment: Congress has completely deregulated the airline industry. In response, an entrepreneur has founded Packenheet Airways. Packenheet is unique in that it allows anyone and everyone to carry a handgun onboard its flights, with these conditions: 1. There are no air marshals and no flight attendants. 2. The crew is sealed into an armor-lined cockpit and won't go into the passenger area except to save the aircraft from a crash. 3. You may carry only a handgun and 25 rounds of ammunition. 4. No long guns (e.g., shotgun, machine gun, rifle, etc.). 5. No weapon that shoots more than one round per trigger pull. 6. You and your baggage will be searched for anything that can purposely kill more than one human being at a time (e.g., bomb, chemicals, bioweapons, etc.). If such things are found, you may not board the flight. 7. You must sign a waiver that says that you cannot sue Packenheet Airways for anything, up to and including a crash caused by gunplay aboard the airliner, and may not make any insurance claims. What's the incentive? The prices are dirt cheap and they'll fly anywhere you can land a modern airliner, no questions asked. Would you fly on Packenheet Airways?

I'm actually a little surprised by this outcome. The CIA has no doubt been lobbying hard to avoid such a position because it would unseat the DCI from his role as the president's chief intelligence advisor. However, this dual role made for a built-in conflict of interest, so there's good reason to subordinate the DCI to someone responsible only to the president. The question now is whether an intelligence tsar would have the authority -- and the ability -- to enforce the president's wishes on a group of agencies that are accustomed to working autonomously and that have powerful allies in Congress. We shall see.
